description.narrative: There is a large amount being written on the COVID-19 crisis. Most international coverage of the COVID-19 crisis in low- and middle-income countries concentrates on the impact of the disease and the official response – for example the impact of governments’ lockdown measures on citizens. What often goes missing is human agency – the way individuals, communities and grassroots organisations respond to the new challenges, both of the disease and the official response. In all countries, ground-up responsesare emerging to address the gaps in state responses, with governments effectively pushing responsibility down to communities, and more local actors emerging around needs. We have seen new tactics and new issues emerging as the crisis unfolds, with new possibilities for collective action, new models of feminist leadership and mutual care. As the COVID-19 crisis evolves, these exercises in emergent agency can helpinform ‘building back better’ options at local and national level – policies and practices that can turn the crisis into a criticaljuncture for the design of a more equitable and sustainable future. The Atlantic Fellows for Social and Economic Equity (AFSEE) programme of the International Inequalities Institute (III) at the London School of Economics (LSE) is funding and collaborating with Oxfam on a new project, bringing the expertise of practitioners and academics together, in response to the global impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The objective is to advance our knowledge about the impacts of and responses to COVID-19 and contribute to shaping policy and informing wider, public conversations about people and community initiatives. This will be facilitated through multiple streams of work: (1) Primary research and evidence gathering in Somalia, the Philippines, Nigeria and the DRC (2) Secondary data collection through a wide network of interested participants (3) Joint sensemaking and knowledge exchange through various thematic clusters or small communities of practice (4) More wholistic and targeted knowledge dissemination and communications to ensure uptake of ideas

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
